abstract.p: William Manning letter on Gregg Easterbrook's Aug 29 article cites role of greenhouse gases emitted by jet planes in global warming

block.p: ''Get the Easy Greenhouse Gases First,'' by Gregg Easterbrook (Op-Ed, Aug. 29), raises new hope for controlling global warming but doesn't mention a growing source of greenhouse gases that affect the atmosphere: jet exhaust.

''Get the Easy Greenhouse Gases First,'' by Gregg Easterbrook (Op-Ed, Aug. 29), raises new hope for controlling global warming but doesn't mention a growing source of greenhouse gases that affect the atmosphere: jet exhaust.

The United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change estimates that approximately 3.5 percent of the greenhouse gases and particulate matter that contribute to global warming come from jet planes. That figure may rise to as much as 13 percent or more over the next 50 years as fleets grow.

Because the gases that subsonic planes produce, including carbon dioxide, are released in the higher, coldest strata of the atmosphere, they may require 75 to 100 years to break down. Carbon dioxide released at ground level, by contrast, takes only a few weeks to disintegrate.
Maybe we should consider this when planning our travels.
